awd_titl_txt: SemiSynBio-II: Programmable abiotic-biotic interface with planar DNA nanopore electrodes
awd_abstract_narration:
The controlled movement of electrons through the semiconductor nanostructures is the foundation of the entire information technology revolution. In the living systems, information processing also takes place, and it involves well-regulated transport of molecules through a complex network of cells using atomically precise machines likes membrane receptors, channels, and pumps. While there has been several efforts over the last few decades to connect these two radically different systems into one information-processing whole, these efforts have not succeeded, because of the structural, mechanical and biochemical mismatch at the interface of living biological elements and nonliving electronic elements. To solve this mismatch, a new approach to abiotic-biotic interface will be developed, based on DNA nanotechnology, that plays to the strength of both systems. The project will provide numerous training opportunities to various cohorts of undergraduate students at three research universities.

In this work, the investigators will build a DNA based “planar artificial gap junction” inspired by naturally occurring biological complexes, called gap junctions, to enable a programmable, modular, interface between biological elements (like proteins, cells and tissues) and semiconductor devices. Much like how natural gap junctions are formed from the protein/peptide pores that self-assemble at the interface of two cells, artificial gap junctions are formed by precisely positioning a defined number of DNA molecules at the active region of a CMOS device that can convert ionic signals into electronic signals. Using the ability to easily modify DNA nanostructures, the investigators will optimize the performance of these artificial gap junctions as well as make them responsive to arbitrary external signals, including molecular signals. Finally, they use the modular architecture of our artificial gap junction to demonstrate direct electronic read-out of molecular information from  different biomolecular systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this project, we developed and demonstrated a modular interface connecting electronic systems to biological components. Our main approach used programmable DNA nanotubes, which we embedded in both lipid bilayers and bilayers formed by block polymers. By carefully designing these DNA-based structures, we created “gateways” that allow signals and molecules to pass between electronic devices and biomolecular systems.

 

A significant portion of our work focused on running simulations to understand how these interfaces behave. In particular, we explored how different DNA nanotube configurations and membrane materials affect device performance. These simulations helped us refine our designs and guided our experimental efforts.

 

We also found that this platform can precisely measure various biomolecules—ranging from small metabolites to large proteins—down to nanomolar concentrations. Our testing spanned both simple solutions and more complex environments mimicking real biological fluids, such as plasma. This ability to monitor biomolecules in near-real-world conditions opens the door to potential applications in diagnostics, drug discovery, and environmental monitoring.

 

Another key outcome was demonstrating the system’s modularity. We showed that, by swapping out a single recognition element in our DNA-based platform, we could quickly tailor the device to detect different targets. This adaptability could prove valuable for next-generation sensors that must identify a wide range of chemical or biological markers on demand.

 

Intellectual Merit: This project sheds light on fundamental design principles for integrating electronic and biological systems. By combining DNA nanotechnology, membrane science, and electronic engineering, we have advanced our understanding of how to build hybrid platforms that can accurately detect and analyze biomolecules.

 

Broader Impacts: Our work points to new possibilities for low-cost, rapid, and sensitive biosensors. These devices may be deployed in healthcare, environmental testing, and industrial monitoring, broadening access to precise measurements and supporting data-driven decision-making. The knowledge gained could also inspire future research on building more complex bio-electronic interfaces that address urgent global needs in health and sustainability.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Ashwin Gopinath
